ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: NA
The course consisted of live, virtual seminars.
none

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: We gained a lot of knowledge about a broad range of political philosophies, then applied these to specific cases in the real world, which required the development of analytical skill.

I learned how to read political philosophy essays, often multiple, in an efficient way. At the beginning, I would take multiple hours to just get through some tens of pages, but at the end, I could effectively skim the essays to both preserve my time as well as my understanding of the material enough to have a discussion over it. I also learned how to write political analysis essays according to the frameworks we discussed in class, and how to look at a situation from multiple perspectives and philosophies.

Through the conversations held in this class, I gained insight on a variety of societal issues, such as the trade-off between privacy and security. I advanced my knowledge regarding the work of several political philosophers, like John Stuart Mill and Jeremy Bentham, both of whom I was unfamiliar with before. I left this class with more questions than what I arrived with, and I am most appreciative of this, as one of the invaluable skills that I developed in the class was to pose questions that critically analyze a nuanced controversy.
I learned about legal philosophies and theories from thinkers such as Mill, Rousseau, Nozick, and Rawls. I also learned how to apply these theories to real world situations.

I learned how to apply the foundations of political ideologies, such as Mill's harm principle, to real world scenarios. I realized law is very complex in that there is always a trade off between law and freedom and it is difficult finding the right balance where it neither leads to anarchy or tyranny.
critical analysis and debate
I learned a ton about different political/legal philosophies. I also learned how to think on my feet and push myself to develop thoughts and think critically on the fly during class.

This course drove me to think about law and freedom in an entirely new way. It pushed me to challenge my assumptions about the very foundations of American/Western law while providing me a solid understanding of renowned philosophers' work.
I learned about the fundamentals of liberal political philosophy and how they apply to modern issues, such as immigration, inequality, slavery reparations, and cultural conflict.

I started to question everything I was taught to accept about our governments and law systems. While trying to find answers to very complex questions, I learnt to consider various perspectives, even the ones I would normally discard, and evaluate their strengths and weaknesses.

Discussion skills
Analysis skills
Political philosophy theories
Learned about various political philosophies and how to write analytical papers

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The strength of this course is the amount of discussion time we get with the instructor and other students. This allowed us to take our thoughts to their logical conclusions and defend or abandon them.

One possible improvement to the course would be to briefly introduce a political philosophy before the readings are due, so that we know what to expect while reading. Some of the works were tough to get through without prior knowledge.

It was an amazing course that I wish I could take again! Truly the best course I took this semester, and I suspect will be a favorite in all my Yale career. It was exciting to go to and read about, even when I was tired of homework and classes. The beginning of the course was difficult because I had no prior experience with political philosophy or similar essay writing, but I quickly understood how to best spend my time and effort, and the course allowed for great discussion and transitioning between topics. I would say that I wish we could have talked more about certain topics than others according to what our class personally liked, so I wish we had the option to allocate discussion time ourselves a bit.

The strengths of the course are evident in the format of it; I felt like I had a very close relationship to the professor and met with him one-on-one throughout the semester. Due to the small class size, I felt like I had a sizable contribution to the development of the class's intellectual discussions. I enjoyed the essay topics and was able to efficiently utilize the readings from the course to research for them. There's no weakness of the course in my opinion, but if I had to give a comment on how it could be improved, I would suggest that a longer class time would be better because the conversations that occur in this class are incredible, and one can often lose track of time.
Professor Rossas was an amazing instructor. All of the seminars were incredibly engaging and the content we covered interesting and relevant.

Strengths: The seminars were always very engaging and Professor Rosas does a great job pushing us to think deeper and challenging our views. Everyone also brought in very interesting points which made the discussion always lively 

Weakness: The virtual seminar took out the core of seminars which is the ability to naturally bounce ideas off of one another. Because it was done through zoom we had to raise hands and wait our turn to speak and sometimes the conversation would have already gone past what you want to talk about

strengths: open debate, manageable readings, engaging professor, even over Zoom

weaknesses: having to do the class over Zoom

This was the best course I've ever taken. Dean Rosas showed amazing commitment to the class through his thorough feedback and engaging conversation. Every topic we covered was amazingly engaging. There isn't anything I'd change.

Strengths: Everything! Rosas is an ~incredible~ professor who excels at leading open discussions and encouraging students to speak clearly and think deeply about the complex political issues surrounding freedom and its limits.

Our reading material was always very engaging. Our discussions were fierce and always thought-provoking. It could only be better if it was taught in-person, which of course because of the circumstances was not possible.

The professor is incredible at facilitating interesting class discussion and helping students think through challenges. 

The course's discussion-based format began to feel tedious at times and I think the professor could have introduced different exercises. I also think assigning some smaller written assignments in addition to the essays could have been helpful in processing information/ideas.

Strengths: Very engaging and thought provoking. Safe environment that encourages discussion.
Weaknesses: Students leave the course with more questions than answers (this is probably good but frustrating)
The class readings were very interesting and discussions were never dull.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Lectures were virtual. All things considered, the discussion was still lively and interesting, and so the course was a success online.

Raising hands worked surprisingly well with the one or two fingers, and made it so that online discussion was organized but also cognizant and respectful of immediate thoughts. I thought a discussion seminar would be very hard to transfer to zoom, but it was still an amazing class and did better than I thought.
I think the course adapted well to the virtual format. Although virtual discussions are not the same as in-person ones, I we are still able to have lively and intellectually challenging discussions.
success: Zoom
I liked that the zoom chat was open for us to use throughout classes. There were always interesting points and mini convos in the chat that complemented the main discussions pretty well.
Discussions were difficult over Zoom, but Dean Rosas worked hard to ensure every student could speak and respond to classmates.
All of the practices, including the course-assigned writing tutor sessions, were very helpful.
Overall, the course was well adjusted to the COVID conditions. Our virtual environment was never a barrier against our discussions.
Zoom discussions did not flow as naturally as in person discussions would have but even so they were pretty smooth.
Professor Rosas ensured that engagement between students was still as great as it would have been in a regular year.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I definitely recommend this course to any first year that gets accepted to it. You will leave with more questions than when you entered, but that's a good thing!

YES!! A truly amazing course to just think about how our government works and why we have the morals we have. Topics like racism, minorities, hate speech, governing, and so much more were spoken about from even the least popular of perspectives, and I think it will carry on to any class I take from now on.
Absolutely! If you are interested in what the law should be and how it should be applied in society then you will love this class. It was my favorite class this semester.

Yes, this class was one of my favorite classes I've taken so far. The topics were always so interesting and everything we learned is directly applicable to current politics and things happening in the world. Professor Rosas is wonderful and he made the discussions so enganging.
Yes, quite engaging and has fun readings
Definitely!
Absolutely! I would totally (and did, multiple times) recommend this course! Professor Rosas was great and the readings were phenomenal!

Absolutely. Take this course. Dean Rosas certainly knows his stuff and, even more importantly, seriously knows how to teach. I was engaged in every single class and found myself discussing course material in my free time.

YES! Absolutely, without a doubt, 100% take this course! I am not a pre-law student, but this course really helped me expand the way I think about a lot of our present-day political conundrums. I even changed my mind about a few topics, which, as a generally stubborn person, is very unusual for me. If you have the opportunity to take this class, DO IT! In my opinion, everyone should take this class or some version of it, and Rosas is a fantastic professor. This course was a true gem.
Yes, of course! Anyone who wants to develop his/her analytical skills and wants to deal with questions that we otherwise easily ignore should take this course.
Yes! Professor Rosas is an excellent teacher and conversationalist.  His classes were my favourite of the week :)
Yes, it was genuinely very fun and the discussions were always super engaging.
Yes! I would definitely recommend this class to anyone interested in a first-year seminar.

extras.title:
PLSC 030 01
        Law and the Limits of Freedom
